prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity: We request 6 sigma detections of each line based on our model calculations (Table 1 in the SJ PDF file). We note that our model calculations of line fluxes of isolated disks are consistent with the existing observations (Walsh et al. 2013).
Configuration setup: Molecular lines will be contaminated by emission from the surrounding clouds. In order to minimize the contamination as well as make the observations most efficient, we request the beamsize to be almost the same as the disk size. Since the disk radii of the target objects obtained by the HST observations are both 0.09'' (Table 3; e.g., Bally et al. 1998), we choose the desired angular resolution as 0.18''. This proposal aims to measure fluxes of various molecular lines as well as dust continuum emission to obtain physical and chemical properties of proplyds, so we do not need to resolve inside the disks. The high spatial resolution of the ALMA cycle 2 makes it possible to exactly minimize the contamination. Also, velocity profile of Keplerian rotation will be also useful to distinguish emission in disks from contamination.
Correlator setup: Our estimated minimum line profile width (FWHM) for a disk which is viewed face on, is $\sim$ 1 km/s, we request the correlator setup with $\Delta$v$\sim$0.2-0.3 km/s. In inclined systems the linewidth is increased further due to the Doppler broadening caused by rotating disk material.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to observe CN and HCN multi-transition lines towards proplyds in the Trapezium Cluster in Orion in order to estimate gas temperature in the disk surface and investigate fundamental properties of photoevaporation process. The target objects are selected based on Subaru and SMA observations. Photoevaporation is thought to be one of the main gas dispersal mechanisms of protoplanetary disks. Since the gas in the disks control the gaseous planet formation as well as the orbital evolution of planets, understanding gas dispersal mechanism is necessary to understand the planet formation process.
In this work, making use of chemical properties of CN and HCN, we propose to measure gas temperature of surface layer of proplyds by observing their multi-transition lines. Since photoevaporation occurs when thermal energy exceeds gravitational energy, our study will contribute to understanding of photoevaporation process. Proplyds are good targets to study photoevaporation process and environmental effect of star cluster, and our study will contribute to understand origin of diversity of exoplanets.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Earth and Planetary Sciences, Tokyo Institute of Technology

Graduate School of Science and Faculty of Science, Kobe University
Institute for Astronomy, Hawaii at Manoa, University of
ELT (Extremely Large Telescope) Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad Autonoma de Madrid
